---
title: 2D Visualization
---

The 2D plots use [plotnine](https://plotnine.org/), Python's implementation of ggplot2. If you know ggplot2 from R, you're already home. If you don't, the grammar-of-graphics approach means plots build up from layersâ€”data, aesthetics, geometries, scales, themes.

```{python}
from plotnine import ggplot
from ggsegpy import geom_brain, dk

ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk())
```

## Filtering by hemisphere

Often you only need one hemisphere:

```{python}
ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk(), hemi="left")
```

```{python}
ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk(), hemi="right")
```

## Filtering by view

Each hemisphere has lateral (outside) and medial (inside) views:

```{python}
ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk(), hemi="left", view="lateral")
```

```{python}
ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk(), hemi="left", view="medial")
```

## Themes

ggsegpy ships with themes designed for brain plots:

```{python}
from ggsegpy import theme_brain, theme_brain_void, theme_darkbrain

p = ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk(), hemi="left")
p + theme_brain()
```

```{python}
p + theme_brain_void()
```

```{python}
p + theme_darkbrain()
```

## Working with plotnine

Since `geom_brain()` works with plotnine, you can add any plotnine layer:

```{python}
from plotnine import labs, theme, element_text

p = ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk(), hemi="left")
p + labs(title="Desikan-Killiany Atlas", subtitle="Left hemisphere")
```

## Subcortical atlas

The aseg atlas shows subcortical structures in axial slices. The grey outline is the cortex, providing spatial context:

```{python}
from ggsegpy import aseg

ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=aseg())
```

## Tract atlas

White matter tracts from TRACULA:

```{python}
from ggsegpy import tracula

ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=tracula())
```

## Saving plots

```{python}
#| eval: false
p = ggplot() + geom_brain(atlas=dk())
p.save("dk_atlas.png", width=10, height=4, dpi=300)
```

For publication figures, 300 DPI and explicit dimensions give you control over the final output.
